qas.question: Where were the computations for hydrogen bomb worked out?
What was the Monte Carlo method?

answers.text: allowed solutions to complicated problems to be approximated using random numbers

qas.question: Due to slow use of random numbers what was developed?

context: Von Neumann's hydrogen bomb work was played out in the realm of computing, where he and Stanislaw Ulam developed simulations on <a0_0>von Neumann's digital computers<a0_0/> for the hydrodynamic computations. During this time he contributed to the development of the Monte Carlo method, which <a1_0>allowed solutions to complicated problems to be approximated using random numbers<a1_0/>. His algorithm for simulating a fair coin with a biased coin is used in the "software whitening" stage of some hardware random number generators. Because using lists of "truly" random numbers was extremely slow, von Neumann developed a form of making <a2_0>pseudorandom numbers<a2_0/>, using the middle-square method. Though this method has been criticized as crude, von Neumann was aware of this: he justified it as being faster than any other method at his disposal, and also noted that when it went awry it did so obviously, unlike methods which could be subtly incorrect. "Anyone who considers arithmetical methods of producing random digits is, of course, in a state of sin."
